question.title: Java : prevent System.exit, File access, etc... for user defined expression

node.contents: In our application, users are able to define Java expressions that are executed by our main engine (those expressions are method calls only: e.g., Math.abs(42) ). They're executed via reflection.

astNode.text: In our application, users are able to define Java expressions that are executed by our main engine (those expressions are method calls only: e.g., Math.abs(42) ). They're executed via reflection.

node.contents: What are the different solutions to prevent those expressions calling for example System.exit (but as well File access and others...) either directly or via a method call that will internally call eventually System.exit ?

astNode.text: What are the different solutions to prevent those expressions calling for example System.exit (but as well File access and others...) either directly or via a method call that will internally call eventually System.exit ?

node.contents: Note that several different expressions can be executed in different threads. Preventing for example File access with a SecurityManager does not work as the main engine must still be able to access the File system while the expressions are executed.

astNode.text: Note that several different expressions can be executed in different threads. Preventing for example File access with a SecurityManager does not work as the main engine must still be able to access the File system while the expressions are executed.

node.contents: There are too many things in Java which could cause a problem that you might not be aware of. The safest thing to do is to create a list of classes which are allows and run these via a custom class loader in a separate process (so you can kill it safely)

astNode.text: There are too many things in Java which could cause a problem that you might not be aware of. The safest thing to do is to create a list of classes which are allows and run these via a custom class loader in a separate process (so you can kill it safely)

node.contents: For serious dangerous code which most people don't even know is there have a look at sun.misc.Unsafe which allows you to

astNode.text: For serious dangerous code which most people don't even know is there have a look at sun.misc.Unsafe which allows you to

node.contents:
• Access random areas of memory.
  • Create new instance of classes without calling a constructor e.g. new instances of Enums.
  • lock and unlock an objects monitor discretely. (Without a synchronized block)

astNode.text:
• Access random areas of memory.
  • Create new instance of classes without calling a constructor e.g. new instances of Enums.
  • lock and unlock an objects monitor discretely. (Without a synchronized block)

node.contents: You are wrong to say you can't use the SecurityManager -- this is precisely what it's for: hosting untrusted code, as in an Applet container or RMI server. The modern SecurityManager is configured with policy files that grant specific, fine-grained rights, including limited access to the file system. You need to use the SecurityManager, but you need to become an expert in it.

astNode.text: You are wrong to say you can't use the SecurityManager -- this is precisely what it's for: hosting untrusted code, as in an Applet container or RMI server. The modern SecurityManager is configured with policy files that grant specific, fine-grained rights, including limited access to the file system. You need to use the SecurityManager, but you need to become an expert in it.

node.contents: This is an enormous topic; the best thing to do would be to Google "Java security policy files" and just read everything you can.

astNode.text: This is an enormous topic; the best thing to do would be to Google "Java security policy files" and just read everything you can.

node.contents: For example Apache Velocity had a similar problem to solve. They use black listed classes and packages defined in velocity.properties:

astNode.text: For example Apache Velocity had a similar problem to solve. They use black listed classes and packages defined in velocity.properties:

elements.contents: # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- # SECURE INTROSPECTOR # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- # If selected, prohibits methods in certain classes and packages from being # accessed. # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- introspector.restrict.packages = java.lang.reflect # The two most dangerous classes introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.Class introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.ClassLoader # Restrict these for extra safety introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.Compiler introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.InheritableThreadLocal introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.Package introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.Process introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.Runtime introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.RuntimePermission introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.SecurityManager introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.System introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.Thread introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.ThreadGroup introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.ThreadLocal

fragments.text: # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- # SECURE INTROSPECTOR # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- # If selected, prohibits methods in certain classes and packages from being # accessed. # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- introspector.restrict.packages = java.lang.reflect # The two most dangerous classes introspector.restrict.classes =
# Restrict these for extra safety introspector.restrict.classes =

units.rawText: # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- # SECURE INTROSPECTOR # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- # If selected, prohibits methods in certain classes and packages from being # accessed. # ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- introspector.restrict.packages = java.lang.reflect # The two most dangerous classes introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.Class introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.ClassLoader # Restrict these for extra safety introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.Compiler introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.InheritableThreadLocal introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.Package introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.Process introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.Runtime introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.RuntimePermission introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.SecurityManager introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.System introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.Thread introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.ThreadGroup introspector.restrict.classes = java.lang.ThreadLocal

node.contents: The Java security system is the appropriate tool for this. SecurityManager is only a part of this system which you will have to use.

astNode.text: The Java security system is the appropriate tool for this. SecurityManager is only a part of this system which you will have to use.

node.contents: Basically you do not invoke the untrusted code yourself. Instead you will wrap that call into a PrivilegedAction and give that to one of the AccessController.doPrivileged methods. Then the untrusted code will be executed in another ProtectionDomain.

astNode.text: Basically you do not invoke the untrusted code yourself. Instead you will wrap that call into a PrivilegedAction and give that to one of the AccessController.doPrivileged methods. Then the untrusted code will be executed in another ProtectionDomain.

node.contents: So you have to configure two protection domains: One for your engine with full privileges and one for the untrusted code with reduced privileges.

astNode.text: So you have to configure two protection domains: One for your engine with full privileges and one for the untrusted code with reduced privileges.

node.contents: But as Ernest already mentioned: This is quite complicated stuff and not suited to a Q&A site like this. Read up the appropriate tutorials from Oracle and Co. Use the above keywords for your search.

astNode.text: But as Ernest already mentioned: This is quite complicated stuff and not suited to a Q&A site like this. Read up the appropriate tutorials from Oracle and Co. Use the above keywords for your search.

node.contents: I agree with the sentiments -- this is scary stuff -- but rolling your own is less safe than using the platform, IMO.

astNode.text: I agree with the sentiments -- this is scary stuff -- but rolling your own is less safe than using the platform, IMO.

node.contents: @ErnestFriedman-Hill the reason I suggested that was that I didn't know how finely grained access control could be with the SecurityManager.

astNode.text: @ErnestFriedman-Hill the reason I suggested that was that I didn't know how finely grained access control could be with the SecurityManager.

node.contents: What you are doing is crazy. Allowing users to execute arbitrary Java code on your machine is an awful idea and there is no way you can make that safe against Hackers who know their stuff.

astNode.text: What you are doing is crazy. Allowing users to execute arbitrary Java code on your machine is an awful idea and there is no way you can make that safe against Hackers who know their stuff.

node.contents: The only solution I can think of is to create a whitelist of packages and methods that may be used. But trying to blacklist specific actions will never get you there. There is always someone who is smarter than you are when it comes to breaking stuff.

astNode.text: The only solution I can think of is to create a whitelist of packages and methods that may be used. But trying to blacklist specific actions will never get you there. There is always someone who is smarter than you are when it comes to breaking stuff.

node.contents: Update: I have now read more about the SecurityManager and it seems that you can controll package access very finely with it, so I'd suggest you to go with Ernest's answer.

astNode.text: Update: I have now read more about the SecurityManager and it seems that you can controll package access very finely with it, so I'd suggest you to go with Ernest's answer.
